segments.text: I'm awfully tired.
Last week, I went to a meeting, and we started at 9 in the morning, went right through the noon hour until 11 o'clock at night, five minutes.
And I'm pretty pooped out, so if I'm shaky, you'll know it's me.
Oh, that's all right.
Maybe I'll catch you off guard or something.
Yeah, okay.
Explain to me how your interest developed in the oceans.

During World War II, I was a meteorologist in the Navy, and purely by chance, I was sent to Scripps Institution of Oceanography to learn how to forecast sea and swell for the then coming Japanese invasion.
and I was stationed in New Caledonia.
Two of us were to be sent to the Philippines to set up a new weather center there, and one was to come back to Scripps, and we drew names out of a hat, and that's how I got into oceanography.
And came back to Scripps.
Right.
Where's your hometown?
Where were you from?
My hometown, actually, I was born in South Dakota.
I lived for short periods of time in Montana and Astoria and Carleton, but I grew up in Newburgh, Oregon, about 40 miles north of here.
And what did your parents do?
My father was a printer and a beekeeper.
It was quite a combination.
And so you didn't go to school here at Oregon, did you?
I went to school at George Fox College, which was then called Pacific College, and it happened to be in the town that I grew up in.
It was a Quaker college.
And was there even a major in meteorology per se?
No, I got the meteorology after the war started.
I joined the Navy and was sent to the postgraduate school in Annapolis.
That's where you became a meteorologist.
Right.
There seems to be a goodly number of meteorologists, if I may use this word, who end up in oceanography about this time.
Spellhouse, for example, comes through the School of the Air Force and ends up in
directing towards oceanography?
Does there seem to be a particular kinship towards meteorology and oceanography?
Well, I think the reason for this was that there were a lot of meteorologists trained, and when they got out after the war, there was nothing for them to do.
I know that I hadn't planned on going to Scripps, and I wrote a letter to Dr. Carl Rosby at Chicago and asked him what I could do with my meteorology.
He said, well, they're starting a class at Scripps.
Why don't I go down there?
And the class was in oceanography?
It was the first class that was set up in oceanography, and almost everyone was a meteorologist that was in the class.
Who was in that class with you?
Oh, I never can remember them all.
Bob Reed, John Cochran from Texas A&M, Dale Leaper,
William Cameron, I'd have to look up the group.
Sure, I know.

The only point of that question is that right at Scripps, right at this time right after the war, there seems to be a tremendous surge of intellectual interest in oceanography, and a goodly number of really first-rate oceanographers appear.
Do you have any particular explanation for that?
Well, I think during World War II we found out that
that we really didn't know much about sound transmission in the ocean or about sea and swell, any of these things that the Navy needed to know.
And Dr. Sferdip then, right after the war, set up this class in which he invited 15, selected 15 people to come into this class.
And it just was a step in function.
OK. And while you were there at Scripps, I think this is 46, is it not?
This was in September of 1946.
Yeah, OK. Now, while you were there in 46,
I assume that at least that you were following a graduate degree in oceanography to lead towards a Ph.D. Is this correct?
This is right.
We all enrolled for master's degrees.
We all had bachelor's degrees plus some advanced training in meteorology.
So we minored in meteorology at UCLA and used our credits that we'd gotten in the various service schools and all of our group majored in physical oceanography.
So we were all somewhat homogeneous in our training.
And what did you work on between, let's say, 46, 47, and 48?
Were you directed already towards a particular research topic?
We all had jobs at Scripps.
We were all graduate research assistants.
And I was in charge of the Navy processing section for bathothermographs for the Pacific Ocean.
And I had about five or six people working for me.
And I worked at that until I left.
Okay.
You should have known about the BT already pretty well.
Didn't you use it in meteorology?
No.
I'd never heard of it until I got the experience.
Never heard of it.
It was invented during the war.
I'd never heard of oceanography before I went down there.
Okay.
It's something entirely new to me.
So this was indeed a deep ocean movie.
Well, from a guy from the Dakotas and then Oregon, I suspect at least Southern California had been a little different.
Right.
It was quite different.
Were you already married then?
Yes, I was married before the war.
Okay.
So then the point is you're already a mature student then, anxious to...
Yes, I was in my late 20s at that time.
Most of us, there were one or two fellows that had gotten into meteorology right out of college, but most of us were in our late 20s.
And what was your master's degree problem, if I may ask?
At that time, we had so much coursework to do that they didn't require a problem.
So each one of us got a master's degree just with coursework.
OK. And then you go on to work towards a PhD?
Right.
And I did my PhD in light scattering and turbid waters.
And with whom did you work?
I started out under and he left right about the middle of my graduate career.
And then I finished up with Carl Eckert.
If it's fair to say, what oceanographers had an impact upon you that helped to direct your career?
Anyone you'd like to name by name?
Well, I think Dr. Spurduck had the greatest effect.
Most people don't realize or haven't heard that Spurduck was well-known in his own country as a sociologist and writer on things that had to do with other than science.
He was a very, very fine person.
What was he like?
Well, he was kind of down to earth.
He came from a family of preachers and Arctic explorers, which is, again, quite a combination.
And well, he just knew people, liked people, and was just inspirational, if I can use that term.
And then is he whom you think helps to direct your early work towards light scattering?
No, I'm not sure just how I got into light scattering.
I had not started to work on my thesis until after he'd gone, and I was pretty well into life scattering before I went to Carl Eckert and asked him if he would be my thesis director.
So I really did it all on my own.
Okay.
Well, it seems many people have commented how close-knit the early community was at Scripps at this time, and how they've become unhappier as graduate schools have become fragmented.
But yet your experience would seem to indicate that you were pretty well left on your own at Scripps.
Is that the wrong inference to draw?
I think Scripps has a tendency to let people do, to work on their own if they'll do it.
This was my impression at any rate.
And you leave Scripps to go to Johns Hopkins, is that correct?
Right, I left Scripps in 1948 with Don Pritchard to start the Chesapeake Bay Institute at Johns Hopkins.
And what were to be the goals of the Chesapeake Bay Institute, which you ended up directing?
No, I never was director.
I was associate director.
Associate, okay, I'm sorry.
Or assistant director, I've forgotten which.
Well, Chesapeake Bay is extremely important as a source of seafood.
There were a lot of problems associated with pollution, freshwater inflow that affected the...
fish and shellfish that were taken out of the bay, and the idea was that the states of Maryland and Virginia and the U.S. Navy would together set up this institute.
The Navy's primary interest, I think, was to have a teaching organization close by so that people who were working in oceanography in Washington could get formal training at Johns Hopkins.
How many of you were first there?
How large was the faculty?
I think we started off, I was the first one to come.
Don Pritchard came second as director, and then we had about three others by the time I left in 1953.
And what did you do and why did you leave?
Well, I'd always wanted to get back to Oregon.
And I'd been writing letters here trying to get something going and hadn't really had much success.

So I made a trip out and talked to the dean of the School of Science at Oregon State and said, if I can bring my own contract and pay my salary, can I come and start an oceanography set up at Oregon State?
He says, fine.
And the Navy was good enough to give me a small contract to get started in 1954.
But 53, 54, you were at the University of Washington, weren't you?
This is right.
I sort of had to get closer to Oregon State to get the thing started, and this is why I took a year's job there.
Okay, and I take it you worked there with Fleming then?
I worked with Fleming, and mainly with Dr. Barnes.
Okay.
He was the principal physical oceanographer then.
And what sort of work did you do?
that year at Washington?
What's our research work?
The Navy had asked me if I would try to get some of the data that they had been collecting there over a period of years in a shape so that it could be used, published in effect.
So I spent most of the time editing data and getting out data reports of one kind or another.
Now, this is, I'm really breaking away from the chronology, but I want to do it right here anyway.
The
I take it most of the work you do with the Navy is through ONR.
Yes, we've never had any contracts that I know of that weren't through ONR.
Okay.
See, ONR started about 30 years ago, just about the time I started out.
Right, now that's exactly what I want to ask you about.
What were your first contacts with ONR?
It begins right at the end of the war.
Well, I was in charge of the bath thermograph section, which actually was supported by some other section in the Navy, and then...
I think I had my first contact with ONR when I went back to Johns Hopkins in 1948, and as I said before, they supported a third of Chesapeake Bay Institute when it started up.
Okay, and with whom did you work in the ONR office?
Gordon Lill was the first person, and he was there for a number of years.
Okay.
So you really then arrive at ONR after Revell has left, I suppose.
This is right.
Okay, now, when Lill tried to fund research, did it seem very mission-oriented then, or did it seem pretty open, deep-water research?
Were research grants difficult to get?
Were they giving block research grants?
Did you have pretty well control of your own money?
Well, at that time, we had pretty well had control of our own money, but we were given block grants, in effect.
They were fairly small.
My first grant here was for $10,000, which took care of my salary and all the assistance I had and everything.
And it stayed that for about five or six years.
So the grants weren't very big, but they were not necessarily mission-oriented.
As long as it was good science, that was all I required.
Okay.
There seems to have been a change in that lately now, ever since...
Oh, really, the Nixon administration, I suppose.
Well, Mansfield had an amendment to some bill in which he directed that the research supported by the Defense Department be more mission-oriented, and then things changed about that.
Okay.
Do you think this was a mistake?
I haven't really thought too much about it.
It's been harder to work under the present rules than the past rules, but I think that...
We really haven't had any great trouble with ONR.
So when you come to Oregon State, then from Washington, you come in effect to almost the founder department, by the way, is what they keep telling me at Washington.
What did you have in mind when you came here?
I'm not a planner.
Okay.
I just thought that I could start a program and make it grow, and I spun my wheels for about five years until 19...
58 or 59 and then things started to happen and I had done some planning during this period and the department was set up in 1959 and then grew very rapidly.
Okay.
Between 55 and 59 what did you primarily work on?
Well, I had a 14-foot skiff and a 15-horsepower outboard and I'd go up and down the coast and work in the estuaries.
I published several papers on the, on Oregon estuaries
And then the Coast Guard had a 40-footer that operated out of Newport, and I persuaded them to go out on a 25-mile line once a month, and we'd go out and do a hydrographic section.
This started about 1955, I think.
So it was a pretty minimal operation.
Did you have any students working with you?
My first student was... Well, I had two students in those days.
One was Bruce McAllister, and the other one was...
named Calloway.
I think Calloway got his degree first, a master's degree, and Bruce got his a little bit later.
These were before we had the department.
I was in the Department of General Science.
Okay, well that answers the next question.
I wonder what department you worked out of.
Right.
Now then, when you began to plan to create a department itself, how did you go about it?
Whom did you talk to?
Well, the department actually came in a hurry.
Gordon Lill had put
$250,000 in the Navy's 10-year plan called Tenoc.
This would have been about 1958.
This $250,000 was to build a boat or a ship for Oregon State, but nothing came of it for a year or so.
I was down in San Diego chairmening a meeting of the western section of the American Society of Limnology and Oceanography, and I got a telephone call.
and this was on a Thursday, I think, and Lil said, this was in June, I have $250,000.
If you can have a proposal in here by Monday, I'll give it to you to build your boat.
I didn't even go back to the meeting.
I just went to the airport and took off.
And as soon as I knew I was going to get the $250,000, I went and talked to the president and said, look, I think this is a real propitious time.

If you could set up a department out of whole cloths, so to speak, I think that we could really make this go, because the Navy isn't going to give me $250,000 without giving me money to run the boat, and this will require other researchers to keep it busy.
And the president said, fine.
So I think it was the only time a department was set up with one person that I've ever heard of.
OK. Now, you were chairman of the department from 59 to 67, right?
Right.
During this period of time also, you talk about Marine Science Center in Newport, Oregon.
Right.
Now, what is that?
We needed a place to dock our vessels.
These are vessels that were going to come in the future.
We had the Akona at that time.
This is the one we built with the 250,000.
And I got to talking to several people in Newport about the possibility of setting up a lab there.
And one or two fellows said, well, fine.
The port has got some nice land on the other side of the river.
We can get a lease for you.
So we began talking.
And pretty soon, they gave us a lease for 49 acres.
And I put a proposal into NSF to build a building.
And while this was still pending, they had several site visits on it.
And I thought I had a fairly good chance of putting up a small building.
The Area Redevelopment Administration came to my attention.
Newport was a very depressed area, and they were trying to figure out some way to get some more jobs in the community.
So I came up with the idea of building a Marine Science Center and said that, well, I can get 60 or 70 jobs, and this might be a good thing to do.
And it took some politicking, but eventually most of the people in town got behind it, and we put in a proposal for $900,000.
90,000, sort of a JCPenney amount, just below a million dollars, and it went right through.
Excellent.
With whom did you work in the area of redevelopment?
I've forgotten the name of the fellow.
He was in Portland.
The main reason it went through was that I knew a lot of people in Washington that were interested in what I was doing, backing me to some extent.
In particular, John Lyman was one of the best ones.
So I got each one of these people to make a pitch to the area redevelopment in Washington.
And I think somehow they were convinced, and they went along with it.
It's interesting that practically everybody else in the country then tried to get some funds, and the door was closed, and nobody else got them.
Nobody else got them built.
Maybe they didn't have John Lyman to make the pitch.
John Lyman did a good job.
So then you're, in effect, wearing two hats in this period.
One is that you're chairman of the department.
The other is you're trying to found in this marine research center.
Right.
While chairman of the department, how did you try to direct the department?
What kind of people did you try to bring into it?
How did you see Oregon State's future in oceanography, if I may use those words?
Well, at the start, it was rather difficult because we didn't have anything.
We were 100% almost, yeah, we were 100% on grants.
And it was difficult to get the first one or two people, and they had to be sort of adventuresome and people that would come.
And Dr. Herbert Ferlander was the first one.
I think the reason he came was he was passed over.
Promotion was a little bit peeved at the University of Washington, and so he came.
I think I was just plain lucky in getting good people.
I didn't really have any criteria other than people that I thought would get along with each other and work as a team.
And then you expected these people to bring in enough grant money to support themselves.
This is the way we had to start out, yes.
And soon after we had the department set up, then we got one or two positions from the university.
And this grew until now.
I think we have about 11 positions paid by the university out of 60 PhDs.
So it's still only a small percentage.
It seemed to me when I checked, you're about 10% state funded.
I don't think we've ever been as high as ten percent.
More like six or seven.
So almost immediately then Oregon State has to support itself and bring people in from grants.
What sort of proposals did you offer?
Did it seem to be some sort of a unique advantage you had here at Oregon State?
Work off the Oregon coast, for example?
The research business is like any other business.
It's like a factory.
If you can get something coming out the other end and sell it, then you can grow.
So that our whole pitch was to get results as quickly as we could and do good research and keep it going.
And it's very highly competitive.
If you produce, you get paid.
If you don't produce, you fall apart.
And so that was then the basis, that was the pressure you worked under?
Yeah.
What about in terms of undergraduate instruction?
Did you try to expand into a general degree in oceanography?
No, I've always felt that a person needed to be a good, to have a good training in one of the basic sciences before they could go on and apply this to the oceans.
While we've taught a lot of undergraduate students, we've never had a degree.
We presently teach something like 600 different students take undergraduate classes.
Now then, you subscribe to the concept that someone should take a degree in the hard sciences and then go on to a degree in oceanography.
They want an advanced degree in oceanography.
What sort of hard science degrees do you prefer for them to take?
Well, we have five different divisions, and in each one they have a different selection.
In physical oceanography, it's either math or physics or a combination of these two.
In geology, geological oceanography, it's geology.
Biological oceanography, biology.
Chemical oceanography, chemistry, and so on.
There seems to be a goodly number of complaints I've heard recently, though, about the failure of mathematical training of the people who are coming into oceanography.
They say it feels as if...
the undergraduate students should take more mathematics.
Would you agree with that?
Well, I'm sure that there are problems with mathematical training.
However, it seems as though we have a good enough selection of students that we really haven't had much trouble with.
Most of them have their math.
Very good.
There also seems to be some complaint among your colleagues that the world of the general oceanographer seems to be collapsing.
that if someone like yourself who came from urology into physical oceanography into other research, that these people are not developed anymore because the field is too specialized.
I have a feeling of sadness because this is true.
Last week I went to a meeting at Scripps in which there were about 50 theoreticians and four or five people that did field work, and I felt a terrible imbalance there.
Now, it...
That's also another complaint, is oceanographers no longer get their feet wet, that the computers have eliminated people going out on ships as much as they should.
Would you agree with that?
Yes, I agree with that.
I believe if you're an oceanographer, you ought to go to sea.
In the field, you ought to go to sea.
Or take the models you're building and test them out in the field itself?
Well, if possible.
I realize that a person can't be everything, but I think that some of the theoreticians are too far removed from the applied science.
From the sea life, all right.
For example, I try to go to sea at least a month every year and average that, and have for years.
That's good.
Then you leave the chairmanship of the department, what, in 67, is that correct?
All right, and then you become associate dean of oceanography.
I became associate dean of research.
Research, I'm sorry.
Yeah, for the university, with oceanography as my specialty.
If you can turn that off for a minute, I'll tell you why.
OK.

Looking back over this first part of your career, as you've sketched it in effect roughly, Scripps, then out to Chesapeake Bay, then as chairman of the department, and then as a dean for research, would you change anything?
Oh, goodness.
I'm sure that if a person thought about it, he might try to change something, but I don't look back very often.
I think that I've been extremely fortunate.
I've had a lot of good luck.
In what way?
Well, breaks.
There are three ingredients.
You try to select good people, you work your tail off, and you have good luck.
I think you make your own luck part of that.
Okay.
Now, in this period, as you're sort of going upward, are there any of your colleagues you would like to mention as people who had sizable effects upon you as you shaped your career along the way?
Well, I think the early staff that we had
helped a good deal.
We started out with Dr. Frolander and Dr. Byrne, Dr. Petullo.
Each one of these people were very fine people, hardworking, liked people, were good with students.
And I think that I was just extremely fortunate to have that team to start off with, because I didn't have to worry about any of them.
They did their work.
They helped.
And the next layer were Bill Piercy, Larry Small, Vern Combe.
They were all exactly the same way.
I didn't have any troublemakers or anybody trying to pull a place apart, and I think that was pretty good.
Now, I just have two or three more questions about administration, and then I want to go back to your academic career.
It's almost as if ONR deliberately tried to establish departments of oceanography in the 50s and 60s, beginning about 57 with IGY.
Are there too many departments of oceanography now?
Well, there are about roughly 15 first-line departments, and I think that's enough.
I don't mean to be selfish, but it takes a certain critical mass to run an oceanographic organization.
You have to have a ship that costs you a million dollars a year to operate, and I believe that perhaps 15 for the country is enough.
And the lid was sort of placed on...
further growth by NSF some years ago by not supporting new outfits with facilities that they needed.

Several states have had powerful enough support from within the state to break this form, or whatever you want to call it, and there have been several states that have started up programs since the lid was sort of placed on it, but not very many.
Delaware, for example, and North Carolina were too.
In accumulating this funding for your university, were you happy to see the division between ONR and NSF?
Did that seem to you to be essentially a good thing?
I think it's an extremely good thing.
I think you need sort of checks and balances.
If we only had one organization to go to, out of 25 or 50 administrators that would have something to do with that organization, there'd be a few that weren't really very good.
And you might run into a situation where you just couldn't move if you just had one person that you were dealing with.
This way you can work with both, and I think this is very healthy.
All right, so I take it then that you would be opposed, to answer your question earlier, you would be opposed towards the move, which seems to be developing, about a super organization.
I'm dead set against it.
I always have been.
Okay, so you think that, in this case, diversity of organizations is better.
Well, I think so as far as support of contract and grant research.
For example, we've had NOAA for a number of years.
And NOAA has been advised time and again by various advisory groups and people
that they'd ought to have better rapport with the universities.
They'd ought to do some granting within universities.
And aside from Sea Grant, which was given to them as a whole package, they really haven't done anything.
And I'm afraid if we had a super organization that the money would be channeled into the organization and the funds outside would tend to dry up.
That would be, you're talking about primarily in-house research.
Right, right.
What's wrong with in-house research?
Guys in NOAA say it's very efficient.
There are all kinds of opinions on this.
I happen to believe that it's much cheaper and more efficient to do it in universities.
By contract.
Some of your colleagues maintain that the problem with in-house research is you get in-house proposal reviews.
This is correct, to some degree.
And they dislike that idea.
We have to be on our toes.
Every single grant or every single proposal we put in gets a thorough working over, and we have to satisfy our peers.
or we can't be funded.
I don't think this is true to this extent in your house.
Also, it has been suggested that one of the problems with the new grant-giving techniques is you almost have to come with a specialized grant.
You expect them to look it over the grant, and then the grant's very limited, and that limits freedom of research.
Now, that's a very poorly put question, but there was a time when you had a blanket amount of money to run a show.

you could say i want to go out for two or three days and try this out and then if it worked then you could take that data and make a solid proposal if it didn't well you just took that two or three day loss well i think there's a tendency in the direction that you're pointing however i have found that if i'm perfectly honest with onr and want to try something a little bit different than i put in my proposal i they've never objected
They've been extremely good and free to allow me to make minor changes and to do some exploratory work.
And this is just really the last question about that, but I take it you've been quite happy in terms of contract work with the government.
You feel like you've had what we call loosely academic freedom and all this kind of thing.
I don't have anything to complain about at all.

Individually, occasionally, I'll put a proposal in, and I'll get some bad reviews and won't get it, and this makes me a little bit angry, but I think the system is about as good as you can develop it.
